Description: Head-rest carved in limestone; trapezoidal block with a concave top; semi-circular depression on one long side while the other is flat; large recessed handles on both small sides to help carrying the object; surface rather smoothed but bit damaged; edges a bit chipped otherwise complete.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Tanis (historic - city), House NE of temple 24
Curator's comments: See Brissaud and Zivie-Coche - Tanis 1987-1997, (1998). p.173, 111 [pl.27].

This head-rest was originally ascribed to Naukratis in the museum register. Close parallel found in Herakleion and dated to the 6th-2nd c BC: Goddio 2008, 261 and 313, No. 147. Goddio, F. (ed.) 2008, Egypt’s Sunken Treasures, 2nd edn., Munich. On the significance of headrests, see especially: Massing, J.-M., Ashton, S.-A. 2011, Triumph, protection & dreams : East African headrests in context East African headrests in context, exhibition held at the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge, 20 Sept. 2011-21 Jan. 2012, Cambridge.
